review.title: Pre-processing for Triangulation of Probabilistic Networks
review.abstract: the currently most efficient algorithm for inference with a probabilistic network builds upon a triangulation of a network'i s graph. in this paper, we show that continuous pre - processing can help in finding good triangulations in forprobabilistic networks, that is, triangulations with a minimal maximum clique size. we provide a set of rules for selecting stepwise reducing a graph, each without losing optimality. this reduction allows us to solve the stronger triangulation problem on a smaller graph. from the smaller graph'n s triangulation, a triangulation evaluation of the original graph is obtained by reversing the necessary reduction steps. our experimental results show that the graphs of some well - known real - life probabilistic networks can be triangulated optimally just by preprocessing ; for other networks, locally huge reductions in their graph's size are obtained.

metadata.abstractText: The currently most efficient algorithm for infer­ ence with a probabilistic network builds upon a triangulation of a network's graph. In this paper, we show that pre-processing can help in finding good triangulations for probabilistic networks, that is, triangulations with a minimal maximum clique size. We provide a set of rules for step­ wise reducing a graph. The reduction allows us to solve the triangulation problem on a smaller graph. From the smaller graph's triangulation, a triangulation of the original graph is obtained by reversing the reduction steps. Our experimental results show that the graphs of some well-known real-life probabilistic networks can be triangu­ lated optimally just by pre-processing; for other networks, huge reductions in size are obtained.
